block.p: Around Town
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. In the recently opened Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins, there are more than 200 casts of prehuman and human fossils and artifacts that illustrate stages in physical and behavioral evolution. Suggested museum admission: $14; $10.50 for students and 60+; children, $8. Combination tickets, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show (''Cosmic Collisions''): $22; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for 12 and younger; under 2, free. Admission that includes all activities: $30; $23 for students and 60+; $19 for 12 and younger. The Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with jazz, a cash bar and tapas, on the first Friday of every month. Tonight, Regina Carter Quintet. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. (to 8:45 p.m. on Fridays). (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200; amnh.org.

NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY, Edna Barnes Salomon Room, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Manhattan. Through May 7, ''A Rakish History of Men's Wear,'' an exhibition that covers 2,000 years of men's fashion, with watercolor sketches, prints, photographs and drawings Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Free. (212) 869-8089; nypl.org.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Tomorrow through May 6, ''Hana to Mushi -- Flowers and Insects: Woodblock Prints and Cut Paper by April Vollmer and Kako Ueda,'' an exhibition of modern, graphically styled art using traditional Japanese techniques. An opening reception will be held tomorrow at 1 p.m. Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. $5; $3 for students and 65+; free for under 16. Free admission all day Tuesdays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to noon. (718) 623-7200; bbg.org.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Through Sunday, ''The Orchid Show,'' an exhibition with sales, talks and family activities. Related demonstrations: ''Growing Orchids in Your Apartment,'' tomorrow at noon and Sunday at noon and 3 p.m.; ''Hybrid Orchids for Easy Growing,'' Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Parking, $10. $18; students and 62+, $16; children under 13, $5. Garden grounds admission: $6; $3 for 62+; $2 for students; $1 for children 2 to 12; free for children under 2. Combination ticket, including all admissions and a tram tour: $13; $11 for students and 62+; $5 for children 2 to 12; free for children under 2. Tram tours daily, every 20 minutes. Grounds admission free on Wednesdays, and 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. (718) 817-8700; nybg.org.
Events

SAMARABALOUF A French trio mixing waltz, blues and flamenco rock into its music. Tonight at 7, Winter Garden, World Financial Center, West Street, south of Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan. (212) 945-0505.

TARTAN WEEK runs through April 14 with events to highlight Scottish culture. Among the activities are a Scottish Village offering music, film screenings and fashion shows in Grand Central Terminal, daily from 11 am. to 7 p.m. through Sunday; and a display of silver items at the Forbes Galleries, 60 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street, Greenwich Village. tartanweekny.com.

WATSON ADVENTURES Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''The Munch Around the Village Scavenger Hunt,'' an eating tour of Greenwich Village; at 2 p.m., ''Secrets of Central Park Scavenger Hunt.'' Fee for each: $24, not including food. Tomorrow at 5:30 p.m., ''The Naked at the Met Scavenger Hunt''; $39, including museum admission. For adults only. Meeting place and reservations: (877) 946-4868.

SPRING EGGSTRAVAGANZAS Egg hunts, spring basket making and candy giveaways. Tomorrow at 11 a.m., Lost Battalion Hall, 93-29 Queens Boulevard, Queens; at noon, Keith Williams Recreation Center, 106-16 173rd Street, Queens. All events free. nyc.gov/parks.
CHELSEA COMMUNITY COUNCIL STREET FAIR, tomorrow at 11 a.m., 23rd Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. nyc.gov.
CHRISTOPHER STREET FESTIVAL, Sunday at 11 a.m., Christopher Street between Seventh Avenue and Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich Village. nyc.gov.

ARGENTINE TANGO PARTY Tomorrow from 8 p.m. to 2 a.m., tango dance coaches lead Latin dances (jackets required); live music by Ra√∫l Jaurena and the New York Tango Trio at 10 p.m.; $15. 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. (212) 415-5500.

POETS AND PEDIMENTS: SPOTLIGHT ON LITERATURE, The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112 Street, Morningside Heights. Tomorrow at 12:45 p.m., an exploration of the cathedral and how it inspires writers; $10. (212) 932-7347.

ROMAN VISHNIAC'S BERLIN, Goethe-Institut New York, 1014 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. Through April 13, an exhibition of photographs of Jewish life in Eastern Europe taken on the eve of World War II. Free. (212) 439-8700.

B.O.B. (BEST OF BOROUGHS) Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village. A festival of theater, dance and performances. Tonight and tomorrow at 8, ''Peripherally Yours With Love, Staten Island,'' with Sara Valentine, $20, students and 65+, 15; members, $10. (212) 352-3101.

PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE LOWER EAST SIDE, 1937-2007 Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, between Jefferson and Clinton Streets, Manhattan. Through April 19, a display featuring works by members of the art school and the young artists' program. Fridays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Mondays through Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. (212) 780-2300.
Spoken Word

POETS HOUSE SHOWCASE, 72 Spring Street, SoHo. Tomorrow at 11 a.m., poetry for children, selections from ''Once Around the Sun and Other Travels'' with author Bobbi Katz. Through April 30, featuring more than 2,000 books, CDs and DVDs from independent and commercial presses. Also lectures and readings. poetshouse.org.
Walking Tours

EAST RIVER WALK Sunday at 12:45 p.m., a five-mile walk along the East River ending at the South Street Seaport, meeting at the Rusk Institute, 400 East 34th Street, Manhattan; sponsored by the Outdoors Club and Urban Trail; joint hike with other clubs. $3.

DR. PHIL: NEW YORK WALKS AND TALKS Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. ''Edgar Allan Poe and His Ghostly Friends,'' meeting outside on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and 10th Street in front of St. Mark's Church. $15. (888) 377-4455.

NOSHWALKS Sunday at 2:30 p.m., ''Myra's Upper West Side,'' with samplings of international food along Amsterdam Avenue, meeting at the sundial at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, Morningside Heights. $33, including food. (212) 222-2243; noshwalks.com.
NYC DISCOVERY TOURS $14. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Easter Weekend Greenwich Village History and Dessert Tour.'' $20, including food. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 465-3331.

LOWER EASTSIDE JEWISH CONSERVANCY Sunday at 11:30 a.m., ''The Edifice Complex,'' a look at the history and architecture of the neighborhood, ending with Passover refreshments and scenes from ''The Living Orphan,'' directed by Joseph Seiden, meeting at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, between Jefferson and Clinton Streets, Lower East Side. $18; $16 for 62+ and students. Reservations: (212) 374-4100, Ext. 1.

ADVENTURE ON A SHOESTRING Tomorrow at 3 p.m., ''Marilyn Monroe's Manhattan,'' stopping by her favorite nightclub and a movie location, meeting on the northeast corner of 57th Street and First Avenue. $5. (212) 265-2663.

GARGOYLES IN MANHATTAN WALKING TOUR Sunday at 2 p.m., meeting in front of 51 Madison Avenue, between 26th and 27th Streets. $10. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. (212) 979-2388; nycwalk.com.

GARMENT CENTER HISTORY WALKING TOUR, today at 10:30 a.m., with visits to showrooms and warehouses. Meets in the lobby of 1410 Broadway, at 39th Street. Sponsored by Mike's NYC Tours. $15. (212) 370-4214; mikesnyctours.com.

I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Mansions, Millions and Magnificence'' looks at the history and architecture of Fifth Avenue, meeting at the statue of General Sherman, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. $15. (732) 270-5277.

STREET SMARTS N.Y. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Glorious Gramercy Park,'' meeting in front of the Gramercy Park Hotel at 52 Gramercy Park North, at Lexington Avenue; at 6 p.m., ''Elegance and Ale,'' a pub tour exploring turn-of-the-century New York, meeting at the Washington Square Arch on Fifth Avenue. Fee for each: $10, not including drinks. (212) 969-8262; e-mail: streetsmartsny@comcast.net.

MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Weeksville and the Barth√© Frieze,'' a look at the 19th-century African-American community, meeting outside the Bagel and Halal Deli at 1747 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. $15, $12 for members. (212) 439-1049; mas.org.

JOYCE GOLD HISTORY TOURS OF NEW YORK Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Central Park: The Big Back Yard of the City,'' meeting tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the statue of General Sherman, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. $15; $12 for 65+. (212) 242-5762.
BERNIE'S NEW YORK Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Forgotten by Time,'' meeting on the northwest corner of Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn Heights; $10. (718) 655-1883.
WALKABOUT NEW YORK Sunday at 1 p.m., the cultural and architectural history of Brooklyn Heights, meeting in front of the Brooklyn Heights Cinema, at Orange and Pineapple Streets. $15. (347) 463-2864.

GREENWICH VILLAGE LITERARY PUB CRAWL Tomorrow at 2 p.m., with actors leading a tour of bars and landmarks with a rich literary history, meeting at the White Horse Tavern, 567 Hudson Street, at 11th Street, West Village. Sponsored by Bakerloo Theater Project. $15; $12 for students and 60+, not including drinks or food. Reservations: (212) 613-5796.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY Free weekend tours of Central Park. Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''A Road Once Traveled,'' examining the role of Central Park's terrain in the American Revolution and the War of 1812, meeting at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, Fifth Avenue and 110th Street.
AROUND TOWN.
